chapter.title: Editing areas and wind areas
chapter.para:
editorarea The area editor allows you to draw and manipulate discrete areas on your depiction. These areas may overlap. This includes fields such as:
system weather
probability of precipitation
ice cover
wind (adjustment area)
Note: Wind areas are a special case. You can define how to calculate a wind rather than setting the wind itself.
The area editor controls appear when you choose to edit a discrete field. (see ) Area edit tools

sect1.title: Defining area values
sect1.para: attribute Each area in a discrete field contains values for a list of attributes. (The attributes have been determined by the System Administrator.) You can set the values for attributes to use when drawing a new area, or when modifying or dividing an existing area. These values can also be saved as a template to use later, if desired. The currently active values for attributes are stored in the Area section. The discrete field also contains values for attributes that are used as default or background values, for regions where no areas have been drawn. These background values are stored in the Background section, and may also be changed.

sect2.title: Selecting and modifying a template
sect2.para: attributecreate template You can select a previously defined template of attribute attribute values from the Memory section, and modify the values as desired.

orderedlist.title: To select and modify a template:

listitem.para:
Select the Draw tool.
Draw
From the Memory section, choose a template.
The values for this template move to the Area section.
In the Area section, click Set.

The Area Attribute dialog box appears. (see ) Area attribute entry menus
You can change the attribute values as desired. Some entries allow for free format typing, some entries have pop-up or scrolled lists of acceptable values, and some numeric entries have spin boxes. Attributes which cannot be modified have a greyed out background. &colwidth2;
Click...To...
Show Original Values Temporarily display the attribute values before changes were made.
Reset Menu Revert back to the original attribute values, before changes were made.
Add to Memory Save the attribute values as a new template in the Memory section.
Close Close the Area Attribute dialog box, without saving any changes.

sect2.title: Deleting a template
sect2.para: attributedelete template Templates created by the System Administrator cannot be deleted from within the &FPA;. If user templates have been added, Delete under the Area section will be active.

listitem.para: Select the Draw, Modify or Divide tool.
Under the Area section, click Delete.
A Delete Memory dialog box appears.
Choose the templates to delete.
Click Delete, or click Cancel to close the dialog box without deleting.

sect2.title: Setting background values
sect2.para: attributebackground sequence You may be able to set default or background values for the attributes for a discrete field. The background attribute values are the same at every time in the time sequence. Modifying the background attribute values at any time changes the background values at all other times as well.

You can change the attribute values as desired. Some entries allow for free format typing, some entries have pop-up or scrolled lists of acceptable values, and some numeric entries have spin boxes. Attributes which cannot be modified have a greyed out background. &colwidth2;

Note: You can display the background attribute values in the Background section by clicking Show.

sect1.title: Defining wind values
sect1.para: wind valuesdefining Each area in a wind field contains a model for calculating the wind, and optional adjustments to this model direction, wind speed, and gust speed. (The models for calculating wind have been determined by the System Administrator.) You can set the adjusted wind model to use when drawing a new area, or when modifying or dividing an existing area. The adjusted wind model can also be saved as a template to use later, if desired. The currently active adjusted wind model is stored in the Area Value section. The wind field also contains an adjusted wind model that is used as a default or background model, for regions where no wind areas have been drawn. This background adjusted wind model is stored in the Background Value section, and may also be changed.

sect2.title: Selecting and modifying a wind template
sect2.para: wind valuesmodify a template You can select a previously defined wind template containing an adjusted wind model from the Memory section, and modify the values as desired.

orderedlist.title: To select and modify a wind template:

listitem.para:
Select the Draw tool.
Draw
The Draw menus appear.
From the Memory section, choose a wind template.
The values for this wind template move to the Area Value section.
Under the Area Value section, click Set.

The Wind Entry dialog box appears. (see ) Wind entry dialog
You can choose a wind model from which to calculate winds from the Base Model list. (Models for calculating winds are determined by the System Administrator.)

You can use the wind direction calculated from the chosen model, with an additional adjustment in degrees (Model Direction), or you can set the wind direction to an absolute value in degrees (Absolute Direction).

You can use the wind speed and gust speed calculated from the chosen model, with an additional percentage adjustment (Model Speed), or you can set the wind speed and gust speed to an absolute value in knots (Absolute Speed). &colwidth2;
Click...To...
Add to List Save the adjusted wind model as a new wind template in the Memory section.
Close Close the Wind Entry dialog box, without saving any changes.

sect2.title: Deleting a wind template
sect2.para: wind valuesdeleting a template Wind templates created by the System Administrator cannot be deleted from within the &FPA;. If user wind templates have been added, Delete under the Area Value section will be active.

listitem.para: Select the Draw, Modify or Divide tool.
Under the Area Value section, click Delete.
A Delete Memory dialog box appears.
Choose the wind templates to delete.
Click Delete, or click Cancel to close the dialog box without deleting.

sect2.title: Setting background wind values
sect2.para: wind valuesbackground sequence You may be able to set a default or background adjusted wind model for a wind field. The background adjusted wind model is the same at every time in the time sequence. Modifying the background adjusted wind model at any time changes the background adjusted wind model at all other times as well.

listitem.para: Select the Draw, Modify or Divide tool.
Under the Background Value section, click Set.

The Background Wind dialog box appears. (see ) Background wind entry dialog
You can choose a wind model from which to calculate winds from the Base Model list. (Models for calculating winds are determined by the System Administrator.)

You can set an adjustment in degrees to be applied to the wind direction calculated from the chosen model, and set percentage adjustments to the wind speed and gust speed calculated from the chosen model. &colwidth2;
Click... To...
Set Save the adjusted wind model to the Background Value section.
Cancel Close the Background Wind dialog box, without saving any changes.

sect2.para: sequence The new background adjusted wind model is applied to all times in the time sequence when you click Set.
Note: You can display the background adjusted wind model in the Background Value section by clicking Show.

sect1.title: Moving an area
sect1.para:
area field editormove To move one or more areas.
Select the Move Area tool.
Move
The move menus appear. (see ) Move menus
Select Include Labels if you want to include labels.
Pick the area(s) to move. (see )
Click the &right; mouse button and select Translate.
The picked areas turn blue.
Pick a reference point on the map and hold the &left; mouse button down.
The reference point can be anywhere; however, if you are moving a portion of the area(s) off the depiction it is important to pick a point that will remain on the depiction after the move. The area boundaries shimmer indicating you can now move them.
Drag the feature feature to the new location and release the button.
The &FPA; then recomputes the field and re-displays the new areas in white.
Note: The areas remain selected until you deselect them, so you may continue to use the Move tools. (see )

sect1.title: Rotating an area
sect1.para:
area field editorrotate To rotate an area in the Area editor:
Select the Move tool.
Move
The move menus appear. (see )
Select Include Labels if you want to include labels.
Pick the area(s) to rotate. (see )
Click the &right; mouse button and select Rotate.
The picked areas turn blue.
Press the &left; mouse button at the point you want to rotate around (the centre of rotation).
Select a second point to form a handle to rotate the area(s) and hold the &left; mouse button down. This is your rotation handle (like the handle of a car window).
A line displays between the two chosen points.
Turn the handle to a new location.
When you have reached the point where the rotation should end, release the &left; mouse button.
The &FPA; displays the rotated area(s).
Note: You can still restore the field if you click Undo at this point.
Note: The areas remain selected until you deselect them, so you may continue to use the Move tools. (see )

sect1.title: Copying an area
sect1.para: area field editorcopy You can copy an area by using Copy and Paste with the Move Area tool.

listitem.para:
Select the Move Area tool.
Move
The Move menus appear. (see )
Select Include Labels if you want to include labels.
Pick the area(s) to copy. (see )
Click the &right; mouse button and select Copy.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Cancel to deselect all areas, or move to another depiction.
Paste is now available.
Note: if pasted to the same depiction the areas will be automatically offset to avoid inadvertent duplication.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Paste.
The areas remain selected until you deselect them, thus Translate and Rotate are available in the &right; mouse button context menu. (see and )
Note: You can still remove the copied field if you click Undo at this point.

sect1.title: Dividing an area
sect1.para: area field editordivide Divide allows you to divide an area. It is often easier to draw the large area and then subdivide it (for example, rain or snow boundary). Divide can also be used to rejoin divided areas.

listitem.para:
Select the Divide tool.
Divide
The Divide menus appear. (see ) Area divide menus
The cursor appears as a knife while inside the map area.
Pick the area to divide. (see )
Select a drawing tool and draw the dividing line.
The start and end points extrapolate to fit in the boundary of the area. One of the new subareas turns blue.
Select values for the first area from the Memory section, or by clicking the &right; mouse button and selecting Set. (see )
or
If the value is to remain the same, click the &right; mouse button and select Leave as is.
The other subarea turns blue.
Select values for the second area from the Memory section, or by clicking the &right; mouse button and selecting Set. (see )
or
If the value is to remain the same, click the &right; mouse button and select Leave as is.
If an area consists of a number of subareas, repeat the divide process until all the areas are defined.

sect2.title: Rejoining divided areas
sect2.para: area field editorrejoin You can use the Divide tool to rejoin the last divided subareas.

listitem.para:
Select the Divide tool.
Divide
Pick the subarea to rejoin. (see )
If the selected subarea can be rejoined, the message indicates that the &right; button can be used to rejoin and the subarea that can be joined turns green.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Rejoin.
Note: The values for the rejoined subareas are taken from those of the first subarea chosen.

sect1.title: Drawing area holes
sect1.para: The extent of an area may be modified by drawing area holes. The holes can intersect the area boundary or be entirely enclosed by the area boundary. (Holes outside the area boundary are automatically deleted.)

listitem.para:
Select the Holes tool.
Draw Hole
Pick the area on which to draw holes. (see )
Select a drawing tool and draw the hole.

sect1.title: Modifying an area
sect1.para: area field editormodify Modify allows you to change the shape of an area boundary or the position of dividing lines, or to change the value of the area or any divided subarea.

You can modify areas or dividing lines with two type of drawing tools. &colwidth2;
Select...To...
a drawing tool draw a new line segment
one of the puck sizes sculpt the existing area or dividing line

listitem.para:
Select the Modify tool.
Modify
Pick the area to modify. (see )
The area boundary turns yellow and the area is covered with a white grid.
Note: You can pick inside or outside an area to modify the area boundary. If you pick outside the area boundary you will not be able to Set the area attributes.
Select the "Freehand" or "Curve" drawing tool.
Draw the new boundary segment. Start and end the line as close to the existing boundary as possible.
The new segment boundary becomes blue and the rest of the original boundary remains yellow.

If the segment shown in yellow is the segment you want to delete, click the &right; mouse button and select Confirm. If you want to delete a different segment, select it and then click the &right; mouse button and select Confirm.

Select the Modify tool.
Modify
Pick the area to modify. (see )
The area boundary turns yellow and the area is covered with a white grid.
Select a puck size. (see )
The number indicates the proportional size of the puck.
The cursor appears as concentric circles while inside the map window.
Choose a smoothing mode. (see )
Click and hold the &left; mouse button to activate the sculpting puck.
The boundary is modified when the puck comes in contact with it.
Release the button when finished.
You can repeat the previous step as often as you wish.
Click the &right; and select Cancel button to complete the edit and deselect the area.

sect2.title: Redrawing a dividing line or area hole

orderedlist.title: To re-draw a dividing line or area hole:

listitem.para:
Select the Modify tool.
Modify
Pick the dividing line or area hole to modify. (see )
The line turns yellow.
Select the "Freehand" or "Curve" drawing tool.
Draw the new line. Start or end the line as close to the existing line as possible.
The new line turns blue and the original line remains yellow.
Note: If the start and end points of the new line are too far away from the existing line, the new line will replace the existing one.
If the line is acceptable, click the &right; mouse button and select Confirm. If the line is not acceptable select Cancel and the line will remain selected you can attempt the edit again.

sect2.title: Sculpting an existing dividing line or area hole

orderedlist.title: To sculpt an existing dividing line or area hole:

listitem.para:
Select the Modify tool.
Modify
Pick the dividing line or area hole to modify. (see )
The line turns yellow.
Select a puck size. (see )
The number indicates the proportional size of the puck.
The cursor appears as concentric circles while inside the map area.
Choose a smoothing mode. (see )
Click and hold the &left; mouse button to activate the sculpting puck.
The line is modified when the puck comes in contact with it.
Release the button when finished.
You can repeat the previous step as often as you wish.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Cancel to complete the edit and deselect the line.

note.para: Sculpting the entire dividing line to the edge of the area (or subarea) that the dividing line is within will delete the dividing line.
Sculpting the boundary of an area hole so that it lies completely outside the area to which it belongs will delete the hole.

listitem.para:
Select the Modify tool.
Modify
Pick the area hole to delete. (see )
The hole boundary turns yellow.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Delete Hole.

sect1.title: Merging information in an area field
sect1.para: area field editormerge You can bring a field from another source and time and merge it into the depiction using the Merge tool.

listitem.para:
Select the Merge tool.
Merge
The merge menus appear. (see )
Select the Source, Issue Time and Valid Time of the other field you wish to merge with your current depiction.
Note: Your System Administrator may configure a field to accept merges from another "compatible" field. If this is the case, there will be a Field list in the Merge Fields area.
Select Include Labels if you want to include labels.
Click Fetch.
The field information from the other source is laid over top of your depiction.
Pick the area(s) to merge. (see )

Finish your selection by pressing the &right; mouse button and select &colwidth2;
Select...To...
Merge merge information in place
Translate move and merge the information
Rotate rotate and merge the information
Note: the picked information remains selected, so you may perform multiple translate and rotate operations.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Cancel to complete the merge.

orderedlist.title: To label any point on the depiction:

listitem.para:
Select the Labelling tool.
Label
Click the &right; mouse button and select a Label Type.

Click the &right; mouse button and select a Label Action: &colwidth2;
Select... To...
Label ActionAdd add a label at a specified point
Label ActionMove facilitates clicking and dragging a label from one location to another (if applicable)
Label ActionShow display a list of attributes of the particular label selected
Label ActionModify change label attributes
Label ActionDelete delete a label
Note: some labels have fixed attributes and cannot be modified. In these cases the Modify tool does not appear.
Pick a point to label using the &left; mouse button.
If you have picked Add...
Labels appear directly where you click.
Note: If your label type requires additional information, an entry menu may appear. You can modify the information as required. Clicking on Set Attributes will add the label.
If you have picked Move, Show, Modify or Delete ...
The nearest label is chosen.
To delete all the labels, click the &right; mouse button and select Clear.

sect1.title: Sampling values from an area fields
sect1.para: area field editorsample You can add temporary labels to the &FPA; window with the Sample tool.

listitem.para:
Select the Sample tool.
Sample
The Sample menus appear. (see ) Sample menus
The cursor appears as cross-hairs while inside the map window.
Select the type of sample you want from the Sample Item area. You can choose to sample All Attributes or a single attribute from the list.
Select the display attributes: colour, size and font.
Pick a point on the depiction.
A temporary label appears.
You can sample as many points as you want.
Note: If you select All Attributes from the Sample Item area, a dialog box appears displaying All Attributes for the point.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Clear to clear the samples from the depiction.

sect1.para: Note: if you select All Attributes from the Sample Item area, the Preset Points option cannot be used. Only single attributes can be displayed with this option.

sect1.title: Labelling wind
sect1.para: wind valueslabel When you label wind, you can label individual points just as you would any other field (see ).
Note: Wind labels appear as a wind barb or arrow.

sect1.title: Sampling wind from a wind field
sect1.para: wind valuessample Sampling wind is like sampling values but with a few more options (see ).

You may sample All Attributes, which will display the parameters the &FPA; would use to calculate the wind at a given point. You may also sample the actual adjusted wind calculated from these parameters, or the wind calculated from a number of other models. The adjusted winds or model winds are usually displayed as wind barbs.

listitem.para:
Select the Sample tool.
Sample
The Sample menus appear. (see )
The cursor appears as cross-hairs while inside the map window.
Select the type of sample you want from the Sample Item area.
You can choose to sample All Attributes, an adjusted wind, or a model wind.
Select the display attributes: colour, size and font.
Pick a point on the depiction.
A temporary label appears.
You can sample as many points as you want.
Note: If you selected All Attributes, a dialog box appears displaying All Attributes for the point.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Clear to clear the samples from the depiction.

sect1.para: Note: if you select All Attributes from the Sample Item area, the Sample Grid option cannot be used. Only single attributes can be displayed with this option.
Note: if you select All Attributes from the Sample Item area, the Preset Points option cannot be used. Only single attributes can be displayed with this option.
